Problem Statement for Star Health: Star Health's current IVR system lacks the intelligence to efficiently address a significant volume of routine customer inquiries, categorized as P3 and P4 priority. This necessitates human agents handling numerous simpler queries, many of which have readily available solutions on the Star Health portal. This inefficient routing contributes to increased call volumes for human agents, longer average handling times (currently 5 minutes), potentially longer wait times for customers, and an underutilization of Star Health's self-service resources. To significantly enhance operational efficiency and improve customer experience, Star Health needs to implement an AI agent over their Ozontel IVR system. This solution must be prioritized for voice interactions and be capable of resolving the maximum possible number of customer queries (P3 and P4). It should also seamlessly guide customers to self-service options on the portal, accurately address P3 and P4 inquiries with a target Average Handling Time (AHT) of 2.5 minutes, and offer seamless handover to human agents or a convenient call-back option for complex issues. Furthermore, Star Health seeks to integrate a WhatsApp solution to provide an additional support channel. Integration with their existing Zoho CRM is also a key requirement.

Use Case Narrative:

A Star Health customer initiates contact via the Ozontel IVR system. An AI agent greets the customer and intelligently analyzes their query. If the query is identified as a P3 or P4 issue, and the solution is available on the Star Health portal or within the AI agent's knowledge base, the AI agent will provide the necessary information or guide the customer towards the DIY solution, aiming for an AHT of 2.5 minutes. For more complex issues or if the AI agent cannot resolve the query, it will seamlessly transfer the call to a qualified human agent. Alternatively, if no agent is immediately available or if preferred by the customer, the AI agent will offer a convenient call-back option. Approx volume - 4lakh calls per month 

In parallel, Star Health aims to implement a WhatsApp support channel integrated with Zoho CRM. Customers can initiate conversations via WhatsApp, and an AI agent (or potentially a human agent) can address their queries. Similar to the voice channel, the goal is to resolve P3 and P4 queries efficiently and escalate complex issues to human agents when necessary. All interactions across both voice and WhatsApp channels will be logged and managed within Zoho CRM to provide a holistic view of the customer journey. The voice channel via the Ozontel integration is the priority for the initial implementation.

Use Case Description: WhatsApp Chat Bot-Coupon Redemption Flow

The primary use case discussed involves a coupon redemption flow facilitated by the WhatsApp chatbot:

Consumers will encounter Essilor advertisements on digital platforms (e.g., Meta).

A call-to-action (CTA) button within these ads will redirect consumers to the Essilor WhatsApp Bot.

The bot will then provide consumers with unique, one-time-use coupon codes.

The bot will also feature a store locator, enabling consumers to find the nearest Essilor partner stores based on their pin code.

Consumers will visit these stores and present the coupon code during their purchase.

Eye Care Professionals (ECPs) at the stores will validate the coupon code (either through the solution or by contacting customer service).

Upon successful validation, the ECP will apply the relevant discount to the purchase.

The ECP will then place an order with Essilor, referencing the coupon code.

Essilor's customer service (CS) team will have access to a real-time dashboard displaying the status of all coupon codes (available, consumed, or expired). The dashboard will be updated as codes are generated and used.

The CS team will verify the coupon code provided by the ECP and record the Rx tracking number associated with the purchase.

If the coupon code is valid, CS will ensure the discount is applied to the order.

Once the order is processed, the coupon's status will be updated to "Consumed," and an SMS/Whatsapp confirmation will be sent to the consumer.

If the coupon code is invalid or a duplicate, the discount claim will be rejected.

The meeting also acknowledged several exception scenarios, including:

ECPs failing to validate codes.

ECPs not passing the discount on to consumers.

Consumer complaints regarding code validity.

Consumers sharing codes.

Opticians misusing codes or encountering order conflicts.

Description:
Technical discovery and solution alignment call conducted with Honda stakeholders regarding the Leads Messenger RFP.

Key takeaways:

The RFP is mandatory due to Honda’s internal procurement policy (6th renewal), not due to a major dissatisfaction with the current solution.

Cost optimization was explicitly mentioned as a pain point.

The current solution runs on the BLIP platform, with support and maintenance provided by a third-party partner. This support is perceived as mostly reactive, with limited proactive optimization or continuous improvement.

The current bot journey is simple and standardized. Regardless of the entry point or selected subject (sales, financing, insurance, services, etc.), all users follow the same flow:

User identification (name and CPF)

Product type selection (automobiles or motorcycles)

Model selection

Dealership definition (by name or proximity)

Lead handover to the Dealership in Salesforce

Subject selection (e.g., consórcio, test-drive, insurance) is used only as contextual tagging and does not alter the journey structure.

Dealership routing is handled via a Honda proprietary API.

Salesforce (myHonda) is the central CRM used for lead creation, routing, and active message (utility template) triggering.

Reporting requirements include message volume, sessions (customer and dealer initiated), MAU, and reconciliation of these metrics against Salesforce data.

Agreed approach:

Propose an AS-IS migration to ensure continuity and low operational risk.

Improvements and optimizations will be proposed separately as an optional roadmap and package of service hours, outside the core AS-IS SOW.

OralSin is looking to enhance their current WhatsApp bot by introducing Generative AI acting as an AI SDR, with the goal of improving lead qualification and increasing appointment conversion.

The main challenge highlighted is a significant drop-off across the funnel (lead → qualification → scheduling → attendance), and the expectation is that a more human-like AI interaction can improve results.

Scope discussed includes:

GenAI-based lead qualification and conversational FAQ (replacing rule-based flows).

Location-based routing (e.g., CEP) to identify the nearest unit.

Controlled knowledge base with guardrails and handoff to human agents when required.

Additional topics were mentioned but are out of scope for the current AI SOW, including unit-level routing via keywords and WhatsApp coexistence.

Next steps:

OralSin to share SDR playbook and relevant materials.

Gupshup to review the current flow and prepare a dedicated GenAI SOW.

Introduced the Conversational Cloud Platform enabling multi-brand and multi-project management under a single login with role-based access across modules (campaigns, agent assist, analytics, etc.).

Highlighted third-party integrations (e.g., WooCommerce) within campaigns, including decision nodes to verify conditions before sending messages.

Confirmed availability of retail-focused automated campaign use-case documentation.

Emphasized the Personaliz module for dynamic customer profiling, segmentation, and cohort creation using data from bots, campaigns, agents, and e-commerce systems.

Clarified that historical e-commerce data can be bulk uploaded (one-time) into Personaliz to improve segmentation and campaign effectiveness.

Introduced Analyzer and Optimizer modules:

Analyzer: consolidated insights on campaign performance, templates, active hours, and error codes.

Optimizer: leverages the 24-hour customer-initiated window for free, personalized, and bulk messaging.

Explained Click to WhatsApp Ads, covering first-party data capture, free retargeting windows on Meta, ROI-driven funnel analytics, and integration with Conversion APIs (CAPI) across Meta and TikTok.

Discussed AI Agent capabilities, including FAQ bots and advanced product recommendation assistants using API-based tools to access external systems (e.g., order history for contextual recommendations).

Outlined AI agent setup components: knowledge sources, personality, skills, guardrails, escalation points, and automated content refresh via website scraping.

Demonstrated product recommendation bot examples, noting that response quality depends on dataset richness and training scope.

Proposed a quick Proof of Concept (PoC) using a limited product set to showcase AI bot capabilities.

Clarified that Freshdesk agent handoff integration is feasible but complex, requiring custom development due to the bot acting as middleware and the need for collaboration and dev credentials.
